title: Cervical Region
raw_text:
For Cervical Disc Herniation



Where is your pain worse?

Neck

Neck-Arm

How did the pain begin?

Sudden

Gradual		(Rule out cervical spondylosis)

Age (Below 40 years)?

Sex (Male)

Do you feel numbness in any form?

Yes

No

Which of these movements currently aggravates your pain?

Flexion (Bending neck forward)

Extension (Bending neck backward)

What movements relieve your pain?

Flexion (Bending neck forward)

Extension (Bending neck backward)

Do you feel more pain when you move your neck?

Yes

No

Do you experience some stiffness in your neck?

Yes

No

Does the pain increase with coughing, sneezing, straining or laughing?

Yes		(Rule out cervical myelopathy)

 No

 Do you have any restrictions with movement around your neck?

Yes 	 (Rule out cervical stenosis)

No

 Do you also have any pain around your lower back, buttocks, thigh or legs?

Yes

No

Does the pain wake you up at night?

Yes

No

Do you feel any form of muscle weakness?

Yes 

No

Do you experience impaired sensations in your arm and forearm?

Yes

No



Observation

Check if cervical rotation on the affected side is less than 60 degrees.

TESTS:

Spurling’s Test (Maximal Cervical Compression and Foraminal Compression Test): The neck is placed in extension, lateral flexion, and axial compression. The test is positive if pain is present and radiates to the arm.

Cervical Distraction Test: The patient lies supine and the neck is positioned comfortably.  The examiner places hand around the patient’s mastoid process. The examiner then slightly flexes the patient’s neck and pull the head towards your torso.Test is positive if the symptoms reduces or is eliminated with traction.



Radiographic confirmation
